excerpt: P200 - % Passing 200 Mesh Wet Test 200 mesh is a critical line coarser than which materials intended for porcelains should not have particles, especially if they are speck producing.

title: % Passing 325 Mesh Wet - P325
description: The amount of particulate material left on a 325 mesh sieve after washing through a measured amount of the powder.
excerpt: P325 - % Passing 325 Mesh Wet Test LSTM-09 In production situations where glazes or other products are ball milled beyond the standard 200 mesh (74 microns) size of many production raw materials, this test is an excellent indicator of consistency of the process and of contaminents that could cause p...

title: +44 and +63 Micron Residue - 44MR
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: 44MR - +44 and +63 Micron Residue Test The particle size of glaze and body slips are checked for residue on 44 and 63 microns (this test is done in all factories in the tile industry, for example).

title: 300F:Ice Water Crazing Test - IWCT
description: Ceramic glazes that do not fit the body often do not craze until later. This progressively stresses the fit until failure point, thus giving it a score
excerpt: IWCT - 300F:Ice Water Crazing Test Most people do not have a dilatometer so they must test the susceptibility of their glazes to crazing by simple observation. Such methods may actually have more value since it can be difficult to link numeric dilatometric results to what will happen in practice.

title: 300F:Ice Water Crazing Test - IWCT
description: Ceramic glazes that do not fit the body often do not craze until later. This progressively stresses the fit until failure point, thus giving it a score
excerpt: IWCT - 300F:Ice Water Crazing Test Most people do not have a dilatometer so they must test the susceptibility of their glazes to crazing by simple observation. Such methods may actually have more value since it can be difficult to link numeric dilatometric results to what will happen in practice.

title: Apparent Porosity - APPO
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: APPO - Apparent Porosity Test This measurement is commonly used in evaluating limestone rock, for example. However it can apply to ceramics for aggregate materials. The figure provides some basis to compare the density of the aggregate particles.

title: Apparent Viscosity (cps) - AVSC
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: AVSC - Apparent Viscosity (cps) Test This figure is only relative if the materials being compared are mixed and diluted the same way. Specify solids content. Viscometers produce values in units known as a centipoise or cps.

title: Average Particle Size (Microns) - AVPS
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: AVPS - Average Particle Size (Microns) Test Particle size analysis falls into two categories: Ultimate and physical. Physical particles are those we can measure using ordinary sieves. Ultimate particles, in the micron range, require the use of specialized devices.

title: Boiling Water:Ice Water Glaze Fit Test - BWIW
description: Ceramic glazes that do not fit the body often do not craze until later. This test stresses the fit, thus revealing if it is likely to craze later.
excerpt: BWIW - Boiling Water:Ice Water Glaze Fit Test This test subjects the clay:glaze interface to a differential thermal stress of 180 degrees F (100C) both hot-to-cold and cold-to-hot (the former accelerates crazing and the latter shivering.

title: Boiling Water:Ice Water Glaze Fit Test - BWIW
description: Ceramic glazes that do not fit the body often do not craze until later. This test stresses the fit, thus revealing if it is likely to craze later.
excerpt: BWIW - Boiling Water:Ice Water Glaze Fit Test This test subjects the clay:glaze interface to a differential thermal stress of 180 degrees F (100C) both hot-to-cold and cold-to-hot (the former accelerates crazing and the latter shivering.

title: Borate LOI - BLOI
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: BLOI - Borate LOI Test The LOI on borate materials is difficult to measure because they have mechanical and crystal water and the temperature to heat samples to to remove only the former is difficult to assess.

title: Bulk Density g/cc (Packed) - BDGC
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: BDGC - Bulk Density g/cc (Packed) Test ASTM-357 The measurement is done on the powdered material after settling. See ASTM C-29 Apparatus: 1. Glass graduated cylinder 50 ml 2. Thin piece of rubber sheet Procedure: Place rubber sheet on the table. Weigh the clean dry glass cylinder.

title: Bulk Density lbs/cu. ft. (Packed) - BDLB
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: BDLB - Bulk Density lbs/cu. ft. (Packed) Test The measurement is done on the powdered material after settling (settling is accelerated in the test procedure). See ASTM C-29 Use the same procedure as the g/cc bulk density test, however multiply answer by 62.42 to get lbs/cubic foot.

title: CEC (meq/100g) - CEC
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: CEC - CEC (meq/100g) Test Cation Exchange Capacity is related to the electrical activity on particle surfaces, it is thus a measure of a materials response to deflocculants, therefore its ability to be deflocculated into a slurry.

title: Carbon content - CCON
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: CCON - Carbon content Test The carbon content of a clay is very important to determine appropriate uses in production. The size of the carbon is also critical, some applications can tolerate finely ground carbon.

title: Clay Water Content - Powder, Plastic - CLWC
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: CLWC - Clay Water Content - Powder, Plastic Test Variables WPOW - Water Content Powder (V) This figure is measured, calculated, and supplied by production.

title: Clay, Silt, Sand Sedimentation Test - CSSS
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: CSSS - Clay, Silt, Sand Sedimentation Test Use this test to make a rough characterization of materials that are a mix of sand, clay and silt. This test produces numbers that are quick to compare.

title: Co-efficient of Linear Expansion - COLE
description: In ceramics, glazes expand with increasing temperature. Being brittle materials, they must be expansion-compatible with the body they are on.
excerpt: COLE - Co-efficient of Linear Expansion Test Most solids expand as they are heated. This expansion occurs in microscopically small amounts and can be observed along a line (linear), across an area and volumetrically.

title: Cold Over Boiled Porosity - COVB
description: Use this test to determine if your fired clay can withstand freeze-thaw and thus be suitable for outdoor use in colder climates.
excerpt: COVB - Cold Over Boiled Porosity Test Clay products both structural and artistic which will be used out-doors must be able to survive the stresses of freeze-thaw.

title: Compressive Strength - CMST
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: CMST - Compressive Strength Test MPa (psi x 103) For example, a firing alumina body might have a value of 2100 (300). Related Information Videos Links URLs http://www.astm.org/Standards/C773.htm ASTM-C773 Crushing Strength By Tony Hansen Follow me on Got a Question? Buy me a coffee and we can talk h...

title: Decomposition Temperature - DTMP
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: DTMP - Decomposition Temperature Test While the ultimate decomposition achieved in ceramics is melting, many materials change their physical form in other ways prior to melting when they reach certain temperatures (i.e. the loss of crystal water, burning away of organics).

title: Deflocculation Demand - DFDM
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: DFDM - Deflocculation Demand Test Refers to the percentage of deflocculant required to bring a slurry to a specific degree of flow and a specific density. For example, a data sheet might specify: "Measured at 305 degrees TTV, fitted with 30swg wire and 11/16" bob (equivalent 5 poise).

title: Density (Specific Gravity) - DENS
description: Measure the density of a dried clay test bar
excerpt: DENS - Density (Specific Gravity) Test This is the density of the actual mineral solid, not the weight of the bulk material powder. This is obvious if this value is being quoted for a mineral but can be confusing if it is for a powder.

title: Density, loose packed (lbs/cu fut) - DNLP
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: DNLP - Density, loose packed (lbs/cu fut) Test The measurement is done on the powdered material before settling. Units are pounds per cubic foot. Variables VAL - Value (V) Related Information Videos Links Tests Bulk Density lbs/cu. ft.

title: Dielectric Strength - DIEL
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: DIEL - Dielectric Strength Test ac-kV/mm (acV/mil) Related Information Videos Links URLs http://www.astm.org/Standards/D116.htm ASTM-D116 Dielectric Strength By Tony Hansen Follow me on Got a Question? Buy me a coffee and we can talk https://digitalfire.com, All Rights Reserved Privacy Policy

title: Dry M.O.R. (50% Silica) - MOR5
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: MOR5 - Dry M.O.R. (50% Silica) Test This is expressed in default units of psi (lb/square inch) and the clay material being tested is mixed with 50% silica. This is done with ball clays since their high plasticity cracks test bars during drying.

title: Dry Strength (Square Bars) - DSTR
description: Measure the tensile strength of a square cross section test bar
excerpt: DSTR - Dry Strength (Square Bars) Test Formula for derice pounds per square inch tensile strength: (3 * F * S) / (2 * W * D * D) Where F = Force in lbs necessary to break the bar S = Span in inches W = Width of bar at break in inches D = Depth of bar at break in inches See DSRN test notes for more i...

title: Dry Strength (kgf/cm2) - DS
description: Measure the tensile strength of a dried clay test bar
excerpt: DS - Dry Strength (kgf/cm2) Test Dry strength is measured by supporting a bar on two points and applying an increasing force from above at the mid point until failure occurs. A formula into which the span, force and diameter of the bar are substituted yields the drying strength.

title: Dry Strenth (Round Bars) - DSRN
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: DSRN - Dry Strenth (Round Bars) Test We have not included procedural records for this definition. See the CDRY and SAWL test for examples. In industry, where articles are handled by machines, it is important to have high green strength.

title: Drying Factor - DFAC
description: The DFAC Drying Factor test visually displays a plastic clay's response to very uneven drying. It is beneficial to show the relative drying performance of different clays.
excerpt: DFAC - Drying Factor Test The DFAC test enables comparing the drying performance (resistance to cracking) of clays. It does this by speed-drying of a 12 cm by 5 mm thick rolled clay disk having a 6 cm metal disk placed on its center (the latter forces all water to migrate to the outer edge).

title: Drying Factor - DFAC
description: The DFAC Drying Factor test visually displays a plastic clay's response to very uneven drying. It is beneficial to show the relative drying performance of different clays.
excerpt: DFAC - Drying Factor Test The DFAC test enables comparing the drying performance (resistance to cracking) of clays. It does this by speed-drying of a 12 cm by 5 mm thick rolled clay disk having a 6 cm metal disk placed on its center (the latter forces all water to migrate to the outer edge).

title: Drying Factor/Water Content/Solubles - CDRY
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: CDRY - Drying Factor/Water Content/Solubles Test This test is suitable for keeping a record of drying performance, firing specks, and soluble salt deposit trends in a production body at a ceramic ware manufacturing facility (i.e. at a porcelain insulator manufacturer).

title: Drying Shrinkage - DSHR
description: Measure the amount a clay test bar shrinks as it dries
excerpt: DSHR - Drying Shrinkage Test Specify the % water content. This is normally based on plastic length, thus to calculate: ( plastic size - dry size ) / plastic size * 100 It is easiest to make bars with a 100mm mark. Then the shrinkage is just 100 minus the dry measurement.

title: Elastic Modulus, 20 degrees C - EM20
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: EM20 - Elastic Modulus, 20 degrees C Test Units: GPa (psi x 106) Often used on electronic grade ceramics and alumina ceramics. For example an alumina body might have a value of 300 (45).

title: Engobe Body Compatibility Test - EBCT
description: A bi-clay test strip curls to demonstrate the drying and fired compatibility or fit of an engobe (or slip) on a ceramic body or of two bodies for marbling.
excerpt: EBCT - Engobe Body Compatibility Test Engobes need to be as compatible with the body in drying, firing and thermal expansion compatible as possible. Engobes are body-like, they do not melt, they are not glazes. That means they have a less developed interface with the body.

title: Engobe Body Compatibility Test - EBCT
description: A bi-clay test strip curls to demonstrate the drying and fired compatibility or fit of an engobe (or slip) on a ceramic body or of two bodies for marbling.
excerpt: EBCT - Engobe Body Compatibility Test Engobes need to be as compatible with the body in drying, firing and thermal expansion compatible as possible. Engobes are body-like, they do not melt, they are not glazes. That means they have a less developed interface with the body.

title: Fired Strength Round Bars - FRRD
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: FRRD - Fired Strength Round Bars Test This property is vital for many types of fired ware (i.e. functional tableware). This test can be difficult and time consuming, however it is quite helpful in determining a clays optimal firing temperature.

title: Fired Strength Square Bars - FSTR
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: FSTR - Fired Strength Square Bars Test See fired strength test for round bars for more information. Fired strength tester This picture has its own page with more detail, click here to see it. Round or square fired bars are subject to a force that tests their tensile strength.

title: Firing Shrinkage - FSHR
description: Measure the amount a clay test bar shrinks as it is fired in a kiln
excerpt: FSHR - Firing Shrinkage Test A percentage value that represents the dry-to-fired shrinkage of a ceramic body. Typically a body is fired to a range of temperatures, each is specified with its shrinkage value. For a comprehensive test to measure shrinkage and porosity, see the SHAB test.

title: Fracture Toughness - FRTG
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: FRTG - Fracture Toughness Test Units: Mpa m1/2 Fractures occur when a solid ceramic is broken into pieces as a result of stress. Failure occurs first by crack formation and then by crack propagation.

title: Frit Fusibility Test - FRFU
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: FRFU - Frit Fusibility Test This is done by preparing a small cylinder of powdered frit and firing it and comparing the fusibility and opacity with a similar cylinder prepared from the standard frit.

title: Frit Melting Range (C) - MLRG
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: MLRG - Frit Melting Range (C) Test This refers to the range at which a glassy material softens and finally melts (crystalline materials melt at a definite temperature, glasses do not).

title: Frit Softening Point - GSPT
description: In ceramics, this is the temperature at which a glaze or glass begins to flow, ceasing to exhibit the properties of a solid.
excerpt: GSPT - Frit Softening Point Test This almost always refers to frits which soften and melt over a fairly wide temperature range (most raw materials melt over a much narrower range).

title: Frit Softening Point - GSPT
description: In ceramics, this is the temperature at which a glaze or glass begins to flow, ceasing to exhibit the properties of a solid.
excerpt: GSPT - Frit Softening Point Test This almost always refers to frits which soften and melt over a fairly wide temperature range (most raw materials melt over a much narrower range).

title: GE Brightness - GEBR
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: GEBR - GE Brightness Test LSTM-14 test method. This is quoted on talc and kaolin data sheets, for example. It is not generally of ceramic interest. Variables VAL - Value (V) Related Information Videos Links Typecodes Material Tests Test conducted primarily on materials use to make bodies or glazes.

title: Glass Transition Temperature - GTTM
description: In ceramic glasses (usually frits) the temperature at which the hard brittle state of the glass changes to the rubber-like state that precedes softening and melting
excerpt: GTTM - Glass Transition Temperature Test This is quoted for ceramic frits and is derived from the graph produced by a dilatometer. The line (representing increasing thermal expansion) climbs steeply as temperature increases.

title: Glaze Body Bond Test - GBBT
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: GBBT - Glaze Body Bond Test In pottery, porcelain and ceramics the body-glaze interface must be well developed for functional ware. This bond is often a matter of consequence at higher temperatures but at lower ones it must not be taken for granted.

title: Glaze Hardness - GLHD
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: GLHD - Glaze Hardness Test If glazes are underfired or have an unbalanced formula (i.e. lack silica:alumina) they can be soft enough to 'cutlery mark', that is, scratchor mark by metal instruments.

title: Glaze Leaching Test - GLLE
description: Simple tests to evaluate the stability of a ceramic or pottery glaze against leaching metals in food or drink.
excerpt: GLLE - Glaze Leaching Test All glass leaches to some extent when it comes into contact with water (or acids and bases), especially if the contact occurs over a period of time or the liquid is hot. This is evident by a change in the gloss and/or texture of the glass surface over time.

title: Glaze Leaching Test - GLLE
description: Simple tests to evaluate the stability of a ceramic or pottery glaze against leaching metals in food or drink.
excerpt: GLLE - Glaze Leaching Test All glass leaches to some extent when it comes into contact with water (or acids and bases), especially if the contact occurs over a period of time or the liquid is hot. This is evident by a change in the gloss and/or texture of the glass surface over time.

title: Glaze Melt Flow - Runway Test - GLFL
description: A method of comparing the melt fluidity of two ceramic materials or glazes by racing them down an inclined runway.
excerpt: GLFL - Glaze Melt Flow - Runway Test Melt fluidity is very difficult to judge from simple observations on glazed ware or samples. Knowing the melt fluidity of a glaze is very important in maintaining consistency, duplicating and understanding it.

title: Glaze Melt Flow - Runway Test - GLFL
description: A method of comparing the melt fluidity of two ceramic materials or glazes by racing them down an inclined runway.
excerpt: GLFL - Glaze Melt Flow - Runway Test Melt fluidity is very difficult to judge from simple observations on glazed ware or samples. Knowing the melt fluidity of a glaze is very important in maintaining consistency, duplicating and understanding it.

title: Glaze Melt Fluidity - Ball Test - GBMF
description: A test where a 10-gram ball of dried glaze is fired on a porcelain tile to study its melt flow, surface character, bubble retention and surface tension.
excerpt: GBMF - Glaze Melt Fluidity - Ball Test Make the test balls by pouring a little glaze on a plaster table. It should dewater in a minute or two. Scrape it up using a rubber rib and flatten it down again (wet side down). Wait half a minute, scrape it up, and put it back down if still too soft.

title: Glaze Melt Fluidity - Ball Test - GBMF
description: A test where a 10-gram ball of dried glaze is fired on a porcelain tile to study its melt flow, surface character, bubble retention and surface tension.
excerpt: GBMF - Glaze Melt Fluidity - Ball Test Make the test balls by pouring a little glaze on a plaster table. It should dewater in a minute or two. Scrape it up using a rubber rib and flatten it down again (wet side down). Wait half a minute, scrape it up, and put it back down if still too soft.

title: Glaze Observations - GLAZ
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: GLAZ - Glaze Observations Test This test could be used maintain the slurry and fired properties of a production glaze. It does not require advanced equipment and produces a set of numbers that can quickly be compared with another batch or day.

title: Hardness (Microindentation) Test - HDMI
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: HDMI - Hardness (Microindentation) Test This test measures hardness by making an indent in a material and measuring it. The following is from http://www.instron.us: A diamond indenter produces an elongated diamond shaped indent.

title: Hardness (Moh) - HMOH
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: HMOH - Hardness (Moh) Test Variables VAL - Value (V) Related Information Videos Links URLs http://www.24carat.co.uk/hardnessmohsscale.html Moh Hardness in Mineralogy & Gemmology URLs http://www.gordonengland.co.uk/hardness/mohs.htm Background Information on Mohs Hardness URLs http://en.wikipedia.org...

title: Heating Microscope Analysis - HMAN
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: HMAN - Heating Microscope Analysis Test Heating microscopes are used for studying the softening of the materials as they melt (especially frits). It is employed to determine the characteristic softening, sphere, half-sphere, glass transition and melting temperatures and its data can be evaluated to ...

title: Heating Microscope Analysis for Frits - HMA
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: HMA - Heating Microscope Analysis for Frits Test Information found at http://www.reimbold-und-strick.de/ This test is important in the assessment of materials for use in glass ceramics. The heating microscope describes the melting of frits during the heating process.

title: Hegman Fineness - HEGF
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: HEGF - Hegman Fineness Test LSTM-17 test method. This is quoted on talc and kaolin data sheets, for example. Here is a good description of the method from gardco.com: In its simplest conception, a Fineness of Grind Gage may be considered essentially a continuous variable screen.

title: I.F.P. (celsius) - IFP
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: IFP - I.F.P. (celsius) Test This is quoted in frit data, however we are not sure what it means yet. It could be: Point of transformation (TP) The beginning of softening (DEB) for a heating rate of 10Â°C/min. The measuring is carried out on glass pieces, which are melted under application condition.

title: Index of Refraction - XREF
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: XREF - Index of Refraction Test A measure of the amount of refraction that it takes when light passes from one medium to another. Variables VAL - Value (V) Related Information Videos Links URLs http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/IndexofRefraction.html Information from World of Physics URLs http...

title: LOI (100-1000C) - LOI
description: Measure how much weight a dried clay test bar loses as it is fired in a kiln
excerpt: LOI - LOI (100-1000C) Test ASTM-20 The weight lost by a ceramic compound during firing. The loss is due to water and organic materials that turn to gases. It is assumed the sample has been boil dried. Some labs also do 25-100C LOI. For a detailed test procedure, see the LDW test.

title: LOI/Density/Water Content - LDW
description: LDW LOI, density and water content test procedure for plastic clay bodies and porcelains
excerpt: LDW - LOI/Density/Water Content Test This test is most valuable to measure the water content of wet clay samples. Knowing water content is especially important when doing SHAB tests.

title: LOI/Density/Water Content - LDW
description: LDW LOI, density and water content test procedure for plastic clay bodies and porcelains
excerpt: LDW - LOI/Density/Water Content Test This test is most valuable to measure the water content of wet clay samples. Knowing water content is especially important when doing SHAB tests.

title: Liquid Limit - LQLM
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: LQLM - Liquid Limit Test Quoted on bentonite data sheets. The liquid limit is the water content above which the clay shows liquid behavior (essentially no shear strength). It is generally done as part of soil analysis and is related to plastic limit (water of plasticity) and shrinkage limit.

title: Median Particle Size (Microns) - MDPS
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: MDPS - Median Particle Size (Microns) Test A quick way of deciding if a clay is coarser or finer than another. The is the micron size when 50% of the clay is finer and 50% is coarser.

title: Modulus of Rupture - Dry - MORD
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: MORD - Modulus of Rupture - Dry Test Modulus of Rupture refers to the resistance of a ceramic bar to breaking when supported on two points and subjected to an increasing force at its midpoint. Default units are psi, otherwise specify.

title: Modulus of Rupture - Fired - MOR
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: MOR - Modulus of Rupture - Fired Test See fired strength tests for information. Can be expressed in lbs/square inch, p.f.s.i., kgf/cm2, or MPa. See Modulus of Rupture with Silica also. Variables VAL - M.O.R.

title: Moisture Content - Powder - MOIP
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: MOIP - Moisture Content - Powder Test This refers to the water content of mineral powders as delivered from the manufacturer. This is often stated as a maximum value. Over time during storage, this will of course change according to the humidity in the storage area.

title: Oil Adsorption (Spatula) - OLAD
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: OLAD - Oil Adsorption (Spatula) Test The oil adsorption of a powders (usually pigments) is defined as the number of grams of linseed oil absorbed by 100 gms of the powder. Thus this test is a measure of the ability of a powder to hold onto oil. APPARATUS AND REAGENTS : 1.

title: Particle Shape (1-7 microns) - PSHP
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: PSHP - Particle Shape (1-7 microns) Test The properties of a powder are determined by particle size, distribution of size, surface chemistry, physics and electrolytics, and particle shape. Shape might be thin flat plate, amorphous, angular, rounded grain, etc.

title: Poisson's Ratio - PRSM
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: PRSM - Poisson's Ratio Test ASTM states: "This test method covers the determination of the elastic properties of ceramic whiteware materials. Specimens of these materials possess specific mechanical resonance frequencies which are defined by the elastic moduli, density, and geometry of the test spec...

title: Pugged Body Properties Overview - PBPO
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: PBPO - Pugged Body Properties Overview Test This test is intended to record observations about the general quality of an extruded clay body that is going to be packaged and sold for use in pottery and industry.

title: Pyrometric Cone Equivalent - PCE
description: Make a pyrometric cone out of a clay or material to see what temperature it bends at
excerpt: PCE - Pyrometric Cone Equivalent Test ASTM C24 -01 Pyrometric Cone Equivalent is measured by making a cone of the material and firing it until it bends to 3 oclock.

title: Pyroplastic Deformation - PPD
description: How to measure the tendency of a ceramic body to warp during firing.
excerpt: PPD - Pyroplastic Deformation Test A clay's 'hot plastic strength', resists the tendency to deform in the kiln. Hot stage microscopes are used for this type of assessment. However, rather than an absolute measurement, often all that is needed is a comparison between the deformation two materials.

title: Reheat Change - RC
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: RC - Reheat Change Test This test is shown on data sheets for materials where thermal expansion is a critical part of their performance. It refers to the % volume increase for a particular temperature. Sometimes a bulk density figure will also be shown.

title: Rheology of a Ceramic Slurry - RHEO
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: RHEO - Rheology of a Ceramic Slurry Test This test collects data about the physical properties related to the rheology of a ceramic slurry. Procedures have not been written yet, this is an outline of the theory and it is generalized to cover as wide a range of slurries and testing budgets as possibl...

title: Shrinkage/Absorption Test - SHAB
description: SHAB Shrinkage and absorption test procedure for plastic clay bodies and materials
excerpt: SHAB - Shrinkage/Absorption Test The SHAB test measures the shrinkage of a dried clay material and the shrinkage/porosities of its fired form across a range of temperatures. The data produced relates to its use in ceramics.

title: Shrinkage/Absorption Test - SHAB
description: SHAB Shrinkage and absorption test procedure for plastic clay bodies and materials
excerpt: SHAB - Shrinkage/Absorption Test The SHAB test measures the shrinkage of a dried clay material and the shrinkage/porosities of its fired form across a range of temperatures. The data produced relates to its use in ceramics.

title: Sieve Analysis 35-325 Wet - SIEV
description: A measure of particle size distribution by washing a powdered or slaked sample through a series of successively finer sieves
excerpt: SIEV - Sieve Analysis 35-325 Wet Test This is a good standard test to measure physical particle size distribution in clay bodies and materials (not ultimate particles).

title: Sieve Analysis 35-325 Wet - SIEV
description: A measure of particle size distribution by washing a powdered or slaked sample through a series of successively finer sieves
excerpt: SIEV - Sieve Analysis 35-325 Wet Test This is a good standard test to measure physical particle size distribution in clay bodies and materials (not ultimate particles).

title: Sieve Analysis Dry - SADR
description: A measure of particle size distribution by vibrating a powdered sample through a series of successively finer sieves
excerpt: SADR - Sieve Analysis Dry Test A set of numbers representing the percentage of dry material particles retained on each sieve in a stack of interlocked sieves with successively finer openings. The stack of sieves is vibrated in a shaker until all material has filtered down through.

title: Sieve Analysis Dry - SADR
description: A measure of particle size distribution by vibrating a powdered sample through a series of successively finer sieves
excerpt: SADR - Sieve Analysis Dry Test A set of numbers representing the percentage of dry material particles retained on each sieve in a stack of interlocked sieves with successively finer openings. The stack of sieves is vibrated in a shaker until all material has filtered down through.

title: Sieve Analysis Wet - SVWT
description: A measure of particle size distribution by washing a powdered or slaked sample through a series of successively finer sieves
excerpt: SVWT - Sieve Analysis Wet Test Also called "Sieve Analysis Water Washed". A set of numbers representing the percentage of material particles retained on each sieve in a stack of interlocked sieves with successively finer openings. The material is slaked and washed through the stack of sieves.

title: Simple Clay Evaluation - SCLE
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: SCLE - Simple Clay Evaluation Test It is not nearly as important to know the chemistry of materials for use in clay bodies as it is to know about their physical properties. Anyone can evaluate a clay material and produce a report that can be very helpful to others.

title: Simple Shrinkage/Absorption - SSAB
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: SSAB - Simple Shrinkage/Absorption Test A shrinkage only version of the SHAB test. Variables Cone - Cone (V) A cone decimal representation of the cone value. DRLN - Dry Length (V) A measurement in decimal inches FRLN - Fired Length (V) A measurement in decimal inches Procedure 100.

title: Solubility - SLBY
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: SLBY - Solubility Test Variables VAL - Value (V) Is it soluble in water, what is it soluble in? Related Information Videos Links Typecodes Material Tests Test conducted primarily on materials use to make bodies or glazes.

title: Soluble Salts - SOLU
description: Evaluate and compare the solubles salts content in clay bodies and materials
excerpt: SOLU - Soluble Salts Test The effectiveness of this barium addition has traditionally been tested by decanting some water from a thin clay/water slurry that has been allowed to settle overnight.

title: Specific Heat Capacity - SPHC
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: SPHC - Specific Heat Capacity Test J/kg*K For example, for high alumina ceramic the value might be: 900 Related Information Videos Links URLs http://www.astm.org/Standards/E1269.htm ASTM-E1269 Specific Heat Capacity By Tony Hansen Follow me on Got a Question? title: Surface Area (m2/gm) - SAMG
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: SAMG - Surface Area (m2/gm) Test A measurement of the total surface area of all particles in a specific amount of powder. It can refer to external surface or all surfaces and should be specified.

title: TGA - TGA
description: This test plots a history of weight changes in a material as it is heated in a kiln
excerpt: TGA - TGA Test This test measures weight changes in a material as it is heated and provides a convenient method for characterizing the decomposition process in inorganics. The test results are plotted on an x-y graph as temperature vs. weight.

title: Tensile Strength, 25 degrees C - TNST
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: TNST - Tensile Strength, 25 degrees C Test MPa (psi x 103) ACMA Test #4 An alumina body might have a value of 190 (30). Related Information Videos Links URLs http://www.astm.org/Standards/C1366.htm ASTM-C1366 Tensile Strength By Tony Hansen Follow me on Got a Question? Buy me a coffee and we can tal...

title: Thermal Conductivity, 20 degrees C - THCO
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: THCO - Thermal Conductivity, 20 degrees C Test Wm degrees K Thermal conductivity is defined as the quantity of heat (Q) transmitted through a unit thickness (L) in a direction normal to a surface of unit area (A) due to a unit temperature gradient (?T) under steady state conditions and when the heat...

title: Thermal Shock Failure - TSFL
description: A simple test any potter can do by making and firing square tiles and using a plumbing torch to see how long before they fracture.
excerpt: TSFL - Thermal Shock Failure Test This imposes a flame on the center of a tile and reports the amount of time until it cracks and the fired size. If rolled from plastic clay, the tile is made to be 3 inches square and 3/16 thick.

title: Trace Elements (ppm) - TREL
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: TREL - Trace Elements (ppm) Test Refers to things like arsenic, cadmium, lead, mercury, selenium, etc. that are not expressed in the chemical analysis of a ceramic. Most ceramic raw materials are earthy substances and thus contain a wide array of trace elements and compounds.

title: Trace Minerals - TRMN
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: TRMN - Trace Minerals Test Variables VAL - Value (V) Just list them, amounts are not usually specified Related Information Videos Links Tests Trace Elements (ppm) Glossary Mineralogy Raw ceramic materials are minerals or mixtures of minerals.

title: Ultimate Particle Size Distribution - UPSD
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: UPSD - Ultimate Particle Size Distribution Test This refers to ultimate particle size, it cannot be measured by using sieves, the units are microns. Testing equipment or a water sedimentation method must be used.

title: Water absorption - WABS
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: WABS - Water absorption Test An indicator of the density and therefore degree of vitrification of a fired clay body. Typically a body sample is fired at a range of temperatures and absorption measurements are done on each to produce a graph of porosity vs. temperature.

title: Water of Plasticity - WOPL
description: A physical data value quoted for plastic materials (clays) used in ceramics to indicate the degree to which they will add plasticity to a body.
excerpt: WOPL - Water of Plasticity Test This value indicates the degree to which the material will add plasticity to a body. In pottery this number indicates the amount of water a clay body needs to pug it to comfortable plasticity and workability.

title: Wet Sieve Residue - WSR
description: Make a quick determination of oversize particles by washing a measured amount of powder through a 150 or 200 mesh sieve.
excerpt: WSR - Wet Sieve Residue Test A simple test of making a visual observation of how much residue, typically from a 50 or 100 gram powder sample, remains on a testing sieve after washing through a slurry of the material.

title: Whole Rock Analysis - WRA
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: WRA - Whole Rock Analysis Test This is simply a chemical analysis of a ceramic material. Enter the data provided by the lab. Variables Ba - BaO (V) Percent Ca - CaO (V) Percent Mg - MgO (V) Percent Sr - SrO (V) Percent Li - Li2O (V) Percent Ti - TiO2 (V) Percent K - K2O (V) Percent Na - Na2O (V) Per...

title: pH (pugged clay) - pHPG
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: pHPG - pH (pugged clay) Test A measure of hydrogen ion concentration. This test is only comparative if samples have the same solids percentages and are prepared the same way. If this number is quoted it should specify the % solids in the suspension or solution (e.g. 4.8 @ 10% solids).

title: pH for dry powder - pHPW
description: Digitalfire Reference Library: Lab Test Procedure Section. Learn to do practical tests on your bodies, glazes and processes and take control
excerpt: pHPW - pH for dry powder Test pH is not a characteristic of powders, but pH of powdered materials is specified as a value @ a specific percentage of solids (e.g. 5%). Apparatus 1. 125 ml glass stoppered flask 2. Glass beaker 100 ml. 3. PH meter 4.
